title: The Hodge Conjecture: Millennium Prize Problem
content:
**The Hodge Conjecture**:

> Every **Hodge class** on a smooth projective variety is a rational linear combination of **algebraic cycle** classes.

**Formally**: For X smooth projective over ℂ:
$$H^{p,p}(X) \cap H^{2p}(X, \mathbb{Q}) = \mathbb{Q}\text{-span of } \{\text{cl}(Z) : Z \text{ algebraic}\}$$

**Status: OPEN** — One of 7 Millennium Prize Problems ($1,000,000)

**Essence**: Bridges topology (cohomology) and algebra (subvarieties).

title: Pure Hodge Structures
content:
**Pure Hodge Structure of weight k**:

- A ℚ-vector space V_ℚ
- Complexification V_ℂ = V_ℚ ⊗ ℂ
- **Hodge decomposition**: $V_{\mathbb{C}} = \bigoplus_{p+q=k} V^{p,q}$
- **Conjugation symmetry**: $\overline{V^{p,q}} = V^{q,p}$

**Origin**: Arises from cohomology of compact Kähler manifolds.

**Example**: H^k(X,ℂ) for a smooth projective variety X.

title: Hodge Classes
content:
**Hodge Class**:

A class α ∈ H^{2p}(X, ℚ) that lies in the (p,p) component:
$$\alpha \in H^{p,p}(X) \cap H^{2p}(X, \mathbb{Q})$$

**Intuition**:
- Rational classes (from topology)
- That are "balanced" in the Hodge decomposition
- These are the classes the conjecture claims are algebraic!

**Example**: The class of a hyperplane section is a Hodge class.

title: Algebraic Cycles and Cycle Class Map
content:
**Algebraic Cycle of codimension p**:

Formal ℤ-linear combination of irreducible subvarieties of codimension p:
$$Z = \sum n_i [Z_i], \quad \text{codim}(Z_i) = p$$

**Cycle Class Map**:
$$\text{cl} : Z^p(X) \to H^{2p}(X, \mathbb{Q})$$

**Key fact**: cl(Z) is always a Hodge class!

**The question**: Is every Hodge class in the image of cl?

title: The Hodge Conjecture Statement
content:
**THE HODGE CONJECTURE**:

For any smooth projective variety X over ℂ and any p ∈ ℕ:

$$\forall \alpha \in H^{p,p}(X) \cap H^{2p}(X, \mathbb{Q}): \exists Z_1, \ldots, Z_n, a_1, \ldots, a_n$$
$$\alpha = \sum_i a_i \cdot \text{cl}(Z_i)$$

where Zᵢ are algebraic cycles of codimension p and aᵢ ∈ ℚ.

**Status**: OPEN since 1950. Resolving this earns a $1M Millennium Prize!
mathContext: Hodge class = ℚ-linear combo of algebraic classes

title: Lefschetz (1,1) Theorem (PROVEN)
content:
**Lefschetz (1,1) Theorem (1924)**:

For ANY smooth projective variety X, every integral Hodge class of type (1,1) is algebraic:
$$H^{1,1}(X) \cap H^2(X, \mathbb{Z}) = \text{Pic}(X) \otimes \mathbb{Z}$$

**Key**: Such classes are first Chern classes of line bundles (= divisor classes).

**Proof idea**: Uses the exponential sequence:
$$0 \to \mathbb{Z} \to \mathcal{O}_X \to \mathcal{O}_X^* \to 0$$

This is the **only proven case** for general varieties!

title: Hodge Conjecture for Curves and Surfaces (PROVEN)
content:
**Proven Cases**:

**Curves (dim = 1)**:
- H^2(X) = ℚ, generated by [X]
- Trivially algebraic ✓

**Surfaces (dim = 2)**:
- p = 0: H⁰ = ℚ·1 (constant functions) ✓
- p = 1: Lefschetz (1,1) theorem ✓
- p = 2: H⁴ = ℚ·[point] (point class) ✓

**Formalized**: `hodge_conjecture_surfaces` proves all surface cases!

title: Counterexamples and Obstructions
content:
**Where Hodge Conjecture FAILS**:

**Voisin (2002)**: Fails for Kähler manifolds!
- Complex torus (Kähler but not projective)
- Has Hodge classes that are NOT algebraic
- Shows **projectivity is essential**

**Atiyah-Hirzebruch**: Fails for integral coefficients!
- Even for projective varieties
- Some integral Hodge classes aren't integral combinations
- Shows **rational coefficients are essential**

The conjecture is very precise in its hypotheses!

title: Related Conjectures
content:
**Web of Conjectures**:

**Grothendieck's Standard Conjectures** (1968):
- Unify Weil cohomology theories
- **Imply Hodge Conjecture!**

**Tate Conjecture** (arithmetic analogue):
- For varieties over finite fields
- Uses ℓ-adic cohomology instead

**Mumford-Tate Conjecture**:
- For abelian varieties
- Relates Hodge structure to Galois action
- **Hodge ⟹ Mumford-Tate**

All remain open and deeply connected!

title: Problem Status: OPEN
content:
**Hodge Conjecture: Still OPEN since 1950**

**PROVEN cases**:
- Curves (trivial) ✓
- Surfaces (Lefschetz + dimension) ✓
- Divisors on any variety (Lefschetz 1,1) ✓
- Special abelian varieties (Deligne) ✓

**FAILS for**:
- Kähler manifolds (must be projective)
- Integral coefficients (must use ℚ)

**Why it's hard**:
- No general way to construct algebraic cycles
- Known techniques only work in low dimension
- Connects complex analysis, algebra, and topology

**Prize**: $1,000,000 Millennium Prize awaits!
